data.what_is:
Agile CRM is a fully integrated CRM with sales tracking, contact management, marketing automation, web analytics, 2-way emails, telephony, helpdesk with a clean modern interface.

With Agile CRM, SMB's can now: 

- Automate their marketing, sales and customer retention process with simple and powerful drag-drop editor
- Convert website visitors directly to leads in the CRM 
- Nurture, track and score leads automatically based on web or email activity 
- Enable multi channel communication with the ability to call or email or tweet to a contact from the same page
- Monitor customer behavior and get real time alerts for customer activity
- Manage helpdesk tickets with all of the customers history in one place 
- Have a detailed record of all of the customer's details and communication history in one page, sorted chronologically 
- See customer data from various other business apps on one page using extensive integrations

all_reviews.review_title: They are partly shut down their mature main product and force you to their new beta startup
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
AgileCRM WAS one of the most holistic and effort products on the market. Clean UI, interconnected functions, detailed statistics.
A CRM as it should be,... till now, it's not anymore. read why in the "dislike" section

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
Wow, I don't know where to start, but let's try: They are disassembling their main flagship product. Overnight, without any big bang, they disabled some core parts of their platform, like "forms", "email campaigns," and "page creator". What will switched of next? No one knows. You are now forced to use their "500apps thing", which is mostly in beta and rich of bugs (you can see them in the lower right corner on their dashboard). 500apps is a mish-mash of single apps collected in one platform. They are not interconnected  (if they are, tell me), they are loose... My opinion is that they are way too early to force their (longterm) clients to that childish platform, which is far away from "production". Now you have to use TWO platforms, with independend contacts lists (they are not in sync), "forms" , "campaings", and "page creators". Why not using a mature "campaign" and mail send platform and pay a few bugs more.. In AgileCRM all your contacts are extensively tagged and tracked, in AgileCRM you can see, when, how which client was contacted, subscribed, called.... At AgileCRM you are not able to create campaings in AgileCRM anymore. When you now try to create a new campaign for a specific target group, you have to export your target audience from AgileCRM into the 500bads... erm.. 500apps and create your campaingn there, with no ability to sync results back to AgileCRM. Are they got crazy? They are still offering things on their page, which are definitely not available anymore, they are simply shut down. It's really, really sad what they have done to themself and are still doing. You can watch how they destroy their state-of-the-art project to a stunted no-name project. No one knows why... I know the world is got crazy these times, but how can you do that AgileCRM?

For people searching for a mature project I highly suggest you to have a look to a more stable product like "ActiveCampaign", "Zoho", "User.com", "sendinblue", "close.com" or similar. Go and create your free account at AgileCRM and 500apps, but first read what they are offering on their Website and then try to find that features in the SaaS itself. Unbelievable, I still cannot get it.

I will delete this post if AgileCRM is going back to "normal", but if not everyone should know what's happening there.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
Be aware that they are migrating their customers from a mature product into a beta product, without warning you.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
OUTDATED, NOT TRUE ANYMORE: Full-service platform for CRM, Helpdesk, customer chat, call-center, Campaign management, pop-ups, Email forms, Customer care, and many more...

all_reviews.review_title: Don't do it!
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
We used to like the low price. Since different features now break every week, however, this CRM system would not be worth it even if it were free. Literally, it has become a total disaster.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
Sending mass emails doesn't work and the promised date for a fix came and went. The calendar link function used to work but suddenly broke months ago and has never been fixed. If you log in from a different location, their system will tell you it is sending a confirmation code but it will never arrive... the "solution" is simply to disable this security feature. The "integration" with O365 is spotty. And speaking of integrations, there are almost none. Downloading of reports is inflexible and very limited. For instance, can I download a report of which contacts opened our last email? Nope. Lots of basic stuff like this can only be viewed on screen.

All in all, AgileCRM is just totally out of date. so much so that it literally feels like their business may be on borrowed time. We are canceling and moving to a new CRM at month's end (won't say which one b/c I don't want people to think this is a competitor just writing an ad). Last thing: don't cancel until you're ready to move because you lose access right away. Yes, that's correct: rather than mainting access through the month you've already paid for, you'll be cut off immediately. Literally everything about this CRM tool is antiquated. Go someplace else for a CRM tool -- literally anywhere else.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
Look, we just wanted a CRM that could manage our contacts, plus add a few extra features like forms for lead capture, maybe a little marketing functionality, too. At first it was okay but as we have grown, Agile just simply hasn't kept up (and trust me, our needs are not that complex). Now that features are routinely breaking it has become a total liability. Implementing a new CRM is a huge pain but we just couldn't stay with Agile.

We had other issues that required tech support during these approximately two years using Agile and similar responses were received.
There is no customer success manager or anybody in charge of your account, even for paying customers like us. Email care@ and hope somebody will answer. Nobody picks up the phone. 100% of the time you get a voicemail and rarely a call back. I never managed to escalate my issues, including the complicated ones. I was always told to wait for an eventual solution.
There is no way to export all the data put on the CRM, only contacts, nothing else so you are locked with them.
Their email deliverability is poor, not sure why. And statistics on deliveries, clicks, etc sometimes disappear with no reason and are never populated.

We use the CRM to track contacts and to create workflows of campaigns tracking email opens, clicks, engagement, etc.

all_reviews.review_title: Some powerful features but unreliable
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
We used Agile CRM primarily for email marketing. Email marketing automations are very flexible. Flowchart oriented automations are easy to design. We found this capability to be significantly better than most of the email marketing tools we researched, including small business market leaders Constant Contact and MailChimp. This was the main reason we chose AgileCRM.

Contact management was very good...again, better than Constant Contact or MailChimp. It was easy to work with contacts and to sort and filter them in different ways.

API was flexible and able to do all we needed to integrate with our user management system.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
Email campaigns were not reliable. Too many instances of campaigns that we determined had not been sent as expected, only to hear from support "Oh, that was our fault, it got bogged down in our server." We could not count on the campaigns just working all the time.

Support was only helpful at a superficial level. We could get help on some small problems, but on other problems, we would get replies like "We have forwarded this to our executives and will be back in touch." But they would not get back in touch. Support didn't always seem to understand or even thoroughly read our requests. If a support request asked 4 questions, only 1 would be answered.

Some features just didn't work in the ways you would hope or expect. For example, in an email drip campaign, there was no way to find out open rates on individual emails, only open rates on the campaign as a whole (if any email was opened, but not which ones).

Reporting was very limited. For example, you could not get any cross campaign reporting on contacts who had unsubscribed like "Give me a list of all contacts who have unsubscribed with the list of campaigns they have unsubscribed from". In looking at contact detail, you could not see which campaigns they had unsubscribed from. Reporting of other kinds was often frustrating and limited.

Email templates that were supposed to be responsive were only sort of responsive. We had lots of issues with emails that didn't look right on different browsers and devices. These are issues that we don't have with MailChimp (which we switched to). Also, designing emails was fairly cumbersome and frustrating. You have to choose Save in 2 to 3 places to actually get an email and a campaign to save. It was easy to lose your work if you weren't careful.

The user interface for campaign management was messy and didn't work as expected. It was very easy to wipe out all the data associated with a campaign if you tried to make a copy of a campaign. Several times, the process to make a copy and then save it wiped out the original campaign losing months of data that could not be recovered. Even after working with AgileCRM for 2 years, it was too easy to wipe things out by mistake and never be completely sure why it had happened.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
We used AgileCRM for 2 years to handle all our email marketing. We were able to have some complex campaign automations that were relatively easy to build. We invested a fair amount of development time in building an integration with our user management system, so had a commitment to use AgileCRM. But ultimately, it was too unreliable for us to continue using it. We couldn't count on campaigns going on as expected and it threatened our business. Sadly, we had to duplicate the integration development work for another system so we could switch away from AgileCRM. This was painful for our small business.

all_reviews.review_title: Agile CRM - Lots of functionality for the price
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
All the features are integrated including CRM, marketing automation, and contact activity tracking. The program also supports service desk activities but I have not used those features. The contact timeline displays all the activity for a contact over time. Triggers based on page visits, form fills, lead scores, etc. can fire off salesperson follow-up tasks or initiate an email drip sequence. Online calendar makes scheduling appointments easy.

I use Agile CRM the most to distribute content via email and for landing pages with forms. I drive visitors to the landing pages from social media, ads, or email. Leads submit contact information to download eBooks or other informational content and are then subscribed to my newsletter and enrolled in long-term email drip campaigns-all automatically.

I have recommended Agile CRM to two of my clients for whom I create content. They are both happy with the product. Also recommended to a colleague. They too are satisfied with the software.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
Limits on the number of automatic sequences and the number of steps in a sequence can make long-term lead nurturing a challenge. Because lead scoring is not a universal setting, you may need to use up nodes in a campaign sequence to increment lead scores.

Data-driven emails are not currently supported. Can't alter the text and images shown to a contact depending on variables in their contact data records.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
For a low-cost way to automate some customer contact and marketing operations, check out Agile CRM. No multi-function software is the best at everything-particularly at economy prices. But this software does a pretty good job at maintaining/manipulating contacts and companies, integrating functions, tracking contact activity, and handling lead-nurturing tasks.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
I switched from another multi-function CRM/AM system that was much more expensive. Agile CRM does the most important things I need at a more reasonable cost. I use the system to distribute email blasts, create landing pages, and run automated document fulfillment and follow-up messaging.

all_reviews.review_title: It just works!
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
I've tried dozens of CRMs over the last few years while helping several clients (and my company) find a solid, all-around CRM system. The best thing about Agile is that it just works. Everything I've tried in the system configures easily and correctly and does what it claims to be able to do.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
The marketing automation system seems very dated and is the only part of the system that I find confusing. There aren't very many readily available email templates and the ones that are available are fairly limited when it comes to design. You CAN import your own HTML designs and they work great, but the workflow for creating an email and a campaign is confusing and can be very frustrating. This part of the system needs improvement. But so many OTHER things works well in the system this is overall a minor complaint.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
It's easy to use, VERY affordable, everything in it just plain works, right out of the box. Support is good and responsive. It's not perfect but no CRM is, but it checks more boxes for functionality and ease of use than any other system I've tried (and I've tried dozens).

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
Automating the collection of contacts and information, as well as expanding the ability to see who is visiting a client's website and where they are going on that site. all_reviews.review_title: Quality CRM for Small Businesses
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
This tool covers the full CRM tools that one would need for most basic needs in sales and marketing. I especially appreciate the online appointment scheduling capabilities that allow people to book time with me in increments as small as 15 minutes.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
In my past life I used Salesforce, and there are some more advanced capabilities that Salesforce had that don't seem as intuitive in Agile CRM. However, the cost of implementing Salesforce and the depths at which one could get in the weeds with that tool - so eaily - really makes Agile CRM look simpler to use by comparison. But, if anyone is an advanced Salesforce user, they may find the Agile CRM tool to be lacking. I wish it had integration with MailChimp. Also, it has been difficult to get my sales team to fully utilize even the basic functions.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
Consider the reason why you are seeking a CRM tool and request an opportunity to trial/demo the tool first to make sure it fits your company goals.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
CRM tools generally help with communication across remote employees, and we have found Agile CRM to be a strong tool for us to use for that purpose. As a small company, we can get by with only 5 licenses, and that's okay with Agile CRM - we still get the full support and training, and that gives us an opportunity to be better sales people and marketers as we are no longer piecing things together in Excel.

all_reviews.review_title: Seems great at first, until you dig in
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
Very simplified. Drag and drop features. Cheap. Has some basic functionality of a full CRM, marketing automation platform and ticketing platform. Can get the job done if this is all that fits into the budget. A good starter platform for marketers that are new to CRMs.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
It's too simple and it's missing some basic functionality that is typical to full CRMs and marketing automation platforms. It will only take a company so far before switching platforms will be required in order to continue growing. Overall, it's just too basic for most companies. Also, when you combine three platforms into one, you are NOT getting the full benefits of any one platform. Instead, you are getting 33% of each. So 33% of a CRM, 33% of a marketing automation platform, and 33% of a ticketing platform. Keep that in mind when making the decision to use this platform. If you're looking for a full CRM and a full marketing automation platform, Agile is the wrong platform. If all you need is something incredibly simple and basic and not fully functional, then Agile is a good choice. Again, this is a starter platform, a beginners platform. Expect to need to switch platforms within a year or two if you want to continue growing.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
Consider looking into other platforms such as Salesforce for CRM, eTrigue for marketing automation and Zendesk for ticketing. In the end, it's better to have three separate platforms that all integrate with each other than a watered down version of three platforms in one. It may seem convenient to have all three in one, but think of it this way. If one breaks, they all break. Also, all three are watered down. You're NOT getting a full version of any one platform. Ask yourself, is it really worth it?

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
Capturing and tracking leads. Implementing a sales process and workflow. Implementing marketing automations and campaigns. The benefits aren't great with Agile. It's very limited compared to what I'm used to. This platform likely won't work well for us for very long. We've already hit some brick walls and limitations within the platform. A full CRM and marketing automation platform is needed.

all_reviews.review_title: Works great for small business

What do you like best about Agile CRM?
The software is easy to get up and running (had some trouble with the DKIM settings but that was resolved) and the CSV import is particularly simple as the mapping is done in software and does not require a new csv to be built before upload. The support has been great so far, needed to use the live chat twice to get the DKIM settings sorted and they were prompt and courteous. Once you get the marketing automation set up it does work properly and fine. Above all else for a small business the starter (or even the free) package is fully fit for purpose.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
The marketing automation campaign set up is a little clunky and quite confusing (although they do offer training sessions). Having the features split between marketing and sales may work for some businesses but in a small business like ours it would be good to combine everything to have it just on one screen.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
Take the training program, things like the marketing automation can be hard to get your head around without some guidance in the right direction. Make sure you or your network administrator has access to the DNS files to implement the DKIM settings.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
Mail merge automation, CRM contact holding, lead scoring and nurturing. Great to have everything in one web based package and we have also started using the iPhone app to manage leads and emails on the road.

This also required integration with our ecommerce solution and helpdesk solution.  We've started using it to track large deal opportunities, and we intended to expand that into sales lead generation and marketing with many of the features we've yet to leverage.

What do you like best about Agile CRM?
The program is easy to set up and work with.  I use template emails all the time which saves me time. I also love the tracking feature and notification of when a user visits my site. I really like the integrations you have with other providers. This has inspired me to explore more solutions to help me run my business better.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
1) I really would like to provide a Customer Portal for my leads to update their information. I know there are tricks to allowing my leads to update their profile information, but this often results in duplicated information.

2)  I would like to send a catered email to a large filtered list of leads greater than 25 without having to link it to a campaign.

3) I would like better reporting. I want to be able to display my leads in a graphic or table and select the grouping criteria, click on the group and work with that selected group.

4) I would like the email summaries that are sent to me every day to include a link directly to each new lead.  Currently, the only link is the email address.

5) I haven't quite figure out how to optimize my use of the point system.

6) I really don't link or use the deals. I would like to be able to set up a sale value to a lead and mark the lead as he/she go through the sales cycle to generate projections.  I don't think this can currently be done.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
Take more advantage of Agile's tutorials and customer support.

Time is being saved as the group grows. I'm just learning how to design campaigns which I think will really help my business.

all_reviews.review_title: Versatile, reliable and affordable CRM and marketing tool
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
Before I have started to use Agile CRM I have been through a very detailed research of the existing CRM solutions. Some of them seemed very good, but expensive, others were affordable, but were missing essential features. I needed something not too expensive, flexible, with easy implementation, not steep learning curve, offering integrations with multiple other software platforms and with good marketing tools as I am a marketing specialist.
When I first tested Agile CRM it seemed to cover all of the above - friendly interface, a lot of integrations supported, not too expensive, easy to implement in our existing ecosystem of software platforms - our own and third party solutions. Our programmers integrated it very fast into our web based telemedicine platform and it started to work from the day one. For the time being we are using the integration with Sendgrid and everything works fine.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
At the moment there is nothing which I dislike too much, so that I will want to describe it here as a downside of Agile CRM.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
Agile CRM is suitable for all types of companies - from small to very large, who need detailed segmentation of their users, rely heavily on e-mail communication and marketing, offer custom support and need their users history of interactions with the company, need to integrate their CRM and automated marketing solution to multiple other platforms and are concentrated on following KPIs in their marketing and customer support.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
The features I use the most are the automated campaigns, which we use to measure the open rate, link clicks and also the actions following on our website. Based on the fulfillment of each step defined in the campaign we were able to segment very precisely our users with the excellent tagging system of Agile CRM, which supports unlimited options to describe and define your users. Based on this segmentation we were able later to decide how to proceed with every user based on his / her previous behavior.
The e-mail templates are quite nice and you don't need any additional external platforms to perform professional marketing. If you are used to make your templates in Mailchimp it is very easy to transfer them here as usage of code is supported as well as custom fields.
The Web rules are also quite nice and efficient, the push notification as well.
The option to filter the users based on the tags, one has attributed to them is of great help to organize your users and the ability to export a filtered segment in csv gives you endless possibilities for further processing and data management.
The chronologic history of every user interactions with a company's e-mail, website and support team gives real opportunity to know your users personally and offer them personalized services.
I highly recommend Agile CRM as a reliable and versatile CRM and marketing solution.

all_reviews.review_title: Extremely Worthwhile Investment - Time & Money || We tried them all, and picked Agile ||
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
FEATURES:  Pretty much every feature under the sun for automation (even correlating user behavior on website into triggers for a campaign is an effective tool due to how well the cookies work).

ON-BOARDING:  We've been able to schedule meetings with our on-boarding team who've been great in giving us real world usage scenarios and helping us settle into the product the right way and waste time looking for a way to do something or figuring out best practices from scratch.  This is HUGE, very few solutions actually have something like this available to you.

CUSTOMER SERVICE:  Top. Notch.  The chat support is great, they're patient and will stick around answering your questions all day, they even pass suggestions to the development team who actually implement them as new features moving forward if it's something you really need.  Which is mind-blowing.

OVERALL:  It's complex and takes effort to learn what the product offers and how to use it.  You're going to have to put the effort in, or it's going to be useless.  That being said, once you put the effort in - Agile CRM gives you super powers compared most of your competition (because it takes effort, and requires learning).

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
Very much a DIY experience, not enough 'sane defaults'.
Needs better testing/preview options for different campaign segments.

But these are something all these 'all-in-one' CRMs need.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
Get the trial of enterprise and run a campaign internal to your company, so you can see what it does.  Make sure to put the tracking code on your website as well so you can setup some web rules as well.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
BOTTOM LINE:
Imagine being in an iron man suit hovering above your competitors firing automated marketing missiles of lead-capturing/qualifying/scheduling sales quota destruction!

all_reviews.review_content:

The software integrates marketing and sales very easily, and users/admins can customize the workflow very easily. We've built an entire inside sale company on the back of AgileCRM.

Build a list of the top 10 most important things you need to do in your business. Don't get stuck with a platform that has a million features / integrations that you won't need/use. Instead, pick something that has everything that's critical, and figure out how to do it well.

Engaged Prospect is an inside sales organization helping over 10 small and midsize businesses market and sell their products/services. We've probably used 8-12 CRMs in the past, and have found that AgileCRM is the best for customizing our sales process, allowing our sales reps to make more phone calls, send more relevant and customized marketing materials and have more conversations than any other inside sales person/team could. We couldn't do it without AgileCRM.

all_reviews.review_title: Build a complete business automation system, without needing a PHD
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
AgileCRM is one complete platform that you can integrate ALL parts of the business sales funnel.

You don't need a PHD to design complicated system architecture and log in and out of 5 different  programs to gain a holistic view of leads, lead conversions, sales and follow-up activities.

AgileCRM provides an intuitive campaign builder, that provides functionality of CRM system which cost 10x per month.

Agile is scalable and allows the initial investment in set-up time/effort and energy to be scaled up to the number of users that are needed to operate the business.  So a start-up stage business can build systems, that can be used when the business grows to a large business.



What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
There is not much not to like.  Agile has a few minor bugs, which are on the development road-map, but that is a normal part of SaaS.

There was difficulties attaching documents to campaign emails, which was a requirement of the systems I was designing.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
- Use AgileCRM for your process design and testing of your processes because it is easy to implement and use, and cost effective.  If your business grows too big for AgileCRM to handle, then made the decision to move to a new platform .....   however; this will not need happen soon.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
I am designing an automation system to capture student enrollment information for a training and assessment organisation.  The big challenge and significant time wasting task is following up student to provide appropriate ID and support documentations for the courses that they are enrolled.

AgileCRM allows us to contact the students easily, and improve course enrollments AND set manual tasks for students that need extra support.  This allows a very small team to perform the  work of a much larger organisation.

I had trialed several other CRM including Infusionsoft, MailChimp-Capsule and due to cost constraints, and ease of use - Agile was a stand-out option.

all_reviews.review_title: I had high hopes for AgileCRM
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
A good competent CRM with very some exciting marketing automation features. Easy pipeline management, quick and easy to send a simple email to a whole list or segment (by tags)
Massive range of Email marketing features. Fairly cheap to start with.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
I wanted more than one deal pipeline but to get that one feature I needed to upgrade all my users from $15/m per user to $50 for all users! That's a massive leap for one little feature. I ended up compromising and sticking to the $15/user plan.
Scheduled call backs and call notes are set up weirdly and again i've had to compromise the way we work to workaround the CRM.
Its good that the system is constantly evolving and changing (daily!) but that means that any documentation or video guides soon go out of date. I've given up trying to read the weekly feature upgrades as i have to wade through 50 useless things to find one that may affect me. My life (and working day) is too short for that.
Some features just seem too hard to get at somehow unless you're a techy. Maybe it's just me being dumb. perhaps I'm not their ideal target customer, but as soon as their instructions include "go to GitHub and..."  I just don't feel the love!.
I've been using it as a CRM for over a year but somehow not managed to leverage their more advanced email and web marketing features. A small business owner can only spend so much of my day figuring out my CRM.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
If you have an existing sales process, define and sketch it out thoroughly, Then try out Agile to see if it fits. i wouldn't bother if you are not expert in tracking codes and making landing pages etc. I also wouldn't bother if you want multiple deal pipelines - its just too expensive. But if you know what you're doing with CRMs and marketing automation, and don't want to pay for such as infusionSoft etc, then maybe AgileCRM is for you.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
To manage my existing client base, I needed a CRM for one or two sales people, with a graphical deal pipeline for both the sales process and the service delivery process. This would then be a firm base from which to launch email and other marketing campaigns. I haven't really managed to go beyond the core CRM functionality onto marketing automation. Lack of simple documentation and intuitive user experience.

all_reviews.review_title: Awesome All-in-one experience
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
Agile CRM is the only platform which helps people like me with growing businesses set up the CRM.
I am able to make calls, record them and also auto responds using emails, push notifications and even offer deals to my customers. All my Sales, service and marketing activities are under one roof and I get a complete picture of a customer - when he initiated the engagement with the website, what all activities lead to a sale and also support him after becoming a customer.

The best feature I like is their easy to use landing page and email builders to create campaigns in a jiffy!

Also setting up my RingCentral account in the tool was so simple and even making calls was a breeze.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
The limit of 5000 free emails per plan, but they have an upgrade package which is very very low as compared with others. Want more emails to be given free :P.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
If you are looking for an economical Sales, Marketing and Service product, Agile CRM is the one! I have recommended to many clients who wanted to automate sales and marketing.

Sales calling, customer tracking, service requests and complete communication with the clients. I am able to schedule my emails and set up campaigns to customers based on specific criteria.

Tags help in the easy filtering of contacts anytime, saving on loads of time.
We can create custom tags and update the contacts, it is like plain clay, which can be molded whatever way you want it to be.

Email creation was too expensive when outsourced to an agency, I am saving a lot by using the drag and drop email editor and also the landing page builder which also is a simple drag and drop interface.

Analytics: This is one feature which helps me to analyze my campaigns performance and take informed decisions to improve the conversions.

all_reviews.review_title: Very well executed product!
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
I evaluated the 10 most popular CRMs before stumbling upon AgileCRM; this CRM was a quick big hit for the simple reason their FREE tier gave me room to really explore the product. I upgraded within a couple weeks once I realized this product does everything I want it do with ease and at a great price point.

What do I like best?  For one, navigation is a breeze (very intuitive), it's flexible and does everything I want a CRM to do, including email tracking and tracking them to our website.  It integrates well with other cloud-based tools and while I haven't needed support they've certainly reached out a few times to be sure I haven't had any issues.  I really love how it tracks our relationships!

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
I have to imagine I'll find something I don't like, but at the moment, nothing comes to mind.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
The biggest problem I wanted to address was tracking our email correspondence with our customers - and track them through the sales and service process.   So far, so good.  We've dramatically improved our ability to keep in contact with out customers - no more customers falling through the cracks, no more weeks without contact...

Speed, User Interface, Integrations, Landing Pages, HTML email templates similar to Mail Chimp, Marketing / Workflow Automation, Simplistic yet extremely robust. 10% the price of other software with fewer features.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
That it took me weeks to find! I seriously searched for an all-in-one CRM and business management solution. Not hours, or days... weeks. Once I finally did, I bought a subscription same-day. Been loving it ever since!

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:

Especially if you consider the other startups I've been/am involved with. This software is golden. Their support is extremely responsive. They seem to be forever enhancing the software, too.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
Communication and information centralization.

Everything is lost in emails. Hard to keep track of every little thing that needs to happen, especially as I'm acquiring more clients. More and more was falling through the cracks.

As a young company, I needed to upgrade my public image to attract even larger clients. Agile CRM has built-in so many features that I don't need to keep paying for separate services to maintain professionalism. Super easy to build a new landing page and point it to a new sub-domain (super easy to do using domains.google.com ) ... Don't even have to for web hosting at this point.

By having nice looking HTML templates, I can state information in a very non-confrontational way. I can represent information in a standardized format with images, rather than allowing for misinterpretation. This is becoming a huge time saver, and severe public image enhancement.

The landing pages are snappy and easy to build. They have built in little pop-ups to try help capture a site visitors email address, to then assign them to an email campaign or flag for follow-up.

I love how it integrates with my Quickbooks Online account, and more importantly, Gmail! ...Their Chrome extension is crucial! Incredibly easy to stay on top of things, add new tasks, and insert premade email templates on the fly! ...You can customize the text and links in the email before sending off, of course.

all_reviews.review_title: Good for small business with a few glitches.
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
Overall it is easy to use and at the lowest level it is affordable for small businesses. The ability to reserve 30 minute blocks of time one-on-one with the support staff has been very helpful. The triggers and tags are easy to understand. I also like that mass emails are easy to send and it is easy to set them up with at least a bit of personalization  and imbed photos in them.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
I understand why you cannot change dates in the timeline so management can know exactly when things have occurred with any contacts, but since I am basically using the CRM only for my own purposes, it is annoying not to be able to change dates or delete things from the timeline. When you ask for an email to be traced so you can see when it is opened by a contact, it continues to register as opening over and over every time the email MOVES in their email cue. That results in many multiple duplicate reports in the timeline that the email was opened, which cannot be deleted. That plugs up the timeline and is super annoying. It is also not possible to connect a document to a contact without having to redownload it every time you want to view it, so I just decided not to attach documents to contacts. It was one of the main functions I wanted...to easily see my quotes for each contact, but this is a very time consuming and clunky process. I was disappointed when I was notified (even though I am sure this is shown someplace in the copy about the different membership levels) that you only get 5 campaigns in the lowest level of service and adding another user doesn't give them any more new campaigns. To bump up to 10 campaigns costs more than 3 times the price per month per user! That pricing seems ridiculous.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
Check to see if you need more than 5 campaigns. If so, you will end up spending as much as the higher priced CRMs, so you may as well check them all out.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
Fewer customers to fall through the cracks, if I use this CRM.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
We have found that our time spent jumping between apps has hugely decreased. Having a one-stop system has allowed us to focus more on the business and less on the business management.

all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
Agile CRM is a simple to use platform that integrates with many 3rd party integrations also has it's own features that you won't find at this price point.

After looking far and wide at integrating a CRM and Marketing Automation platform, for small business, you can't beat Agile CRM.

- Features: There's plenty of them and nothing comes close to it at this price point. There's too many to list. Look at their website for all their features. From Sales, Marketing Automation, Integrations, Service, Web Rules, Triggers, Social plugin, Landing Page Builder, Analytics, Push Notifications....

- Plenty of integrations. The WooCommerce plugin I'm currently testing works like a charm. Tracks and tags all purchasers without an issue. Again, check their webpage to view all their integrations.

- Support: Excellent support over chat that assisted issues with implementation.

- Price: Although only just starting out with their free version. To get the same features you'd be easily paying $50/ month just to start with what they provide you. You won't hurt your pocket investing in this platform and get more than your ROI. Let's hope they keep their price low to assist small business.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
- It's not a big issue but I wish their forms could be customised to look professional like other form builders. This would eliminate integration with other 3rd party forms. If you were tech savvy enough, you'd code your own and keep the integration with Agile CRM.

- Interface: It's not bad, but their email template interface looks a little dated, but it still works fine. When comparing it to MailChimp's email template design, it's a little unfair as Agile CRM provide 10x the features at a cheaper price.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
If you're a small business owner that's concerned with the ever-growing overheads of SaaS platforms for each and every aspect, you can't go by without at least giving this a go.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
- Integrating the many systems into 1 system that will limit the amount of systems/ logins to each and every service.

I would recommend you give it a go. With their feature set and price, you have to wonder how other vendors can charge so much and see a ROI; especially for small business.

all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
I like the Contacts section, where you can add tags easily and in the same way change or remove them. I can quickly filter and find the clients I am looking for.
I also like that you can create campaigns and add clients to send it to or choose contacts and then send a campaign. This makes it a very fluid process and I am not stuck in one way of working. Compared to other system, it is easier to get used to.
I like that you can connect Gmail calendar and also use Gmail to send follow up emails so it is a more personal.
I also love the pricing!

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
The email designing and creation within the system does not work very well. I can see it on the Preview but once the email is sent, then the fonts, images and the grid is completely off and I thought using your designs and system would eliminate this.
We also have our internal design team and they designing it and still if coded from scratch. still some things do not show up compared to the preview.
You need to improve and fix the template issues. It will make our work a lot longer to always make sure the template is working right.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
Better HTML import of email templates. Possibly being able to take Mailchimp templates code and make it easier and quicker to implement those or any other email system that is usually used by clients.
Also more options for email templates.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
We needed a central place that everyone can access and be able to track all that has been done and how the contacts progress from one stage to another - Cold to Warm to Hot leads.
We also needed better reporting and providing actual data to our management and be able to quantify the work we are doing as Sales and Marketing.

We realized using a system specifically geared towards having Marketing and Sales in one is better. I was using Streak CRM to organize contacts and then send emails and design it though Gmail and Photoshop; then using other systems to report, to follow up and reach out to client. We adapted to the process but sometimes you can miss one things or one follow up and it breaks down the system because you are using several different software.

all_reviews.review_title: Very cost effective tool for marketing automation
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
Agile is extremely easy to set up and covers all 3 traditional functionalities of CRM systems (ticketing, lead management and marketing automation), albeit some better than others. Marketing automation module offers some very sophisticated tools such as ability to automate campaigns based on specific triggers such as cart abandonment. It also offers A/B testing, ability to track conversion, set up web rules and has some very useful forms and email templates.

Lead management module offers many of the functionalities found in other systems including reason for loss. Dashboard customisation is somewhat limited.

Agile stands out where customer service is involved. Their team has gone beyond the call of duty on many occasions to help us customise some features.



What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
The service or ticketing module is limited in terms of functionality. Some of the settings for the system are not intuitive; the SLA for ticketing is found in campaigns for example. Synching emails requires you to add yourself as a contact or incorporate into a group which again is counter intuitive. Overall I think there is room for improvement in the customer operability of the system specifically for the more advanced functionalities. Bulk actions are also restricted.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
We mainly use the system for contact management, outbound marketing activities and creating web rules. Compared to other systems in the market, it does offer great value for money as well as great customer service and technical support.

all_reviews.review_title: Agile CRM is an all-in-one Platform that may be trying to do too much.
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
Agile CRM has a variety of really strong features that allow you to easily add and manage all incoming contacts and leads. The feature I find most useful for our company would be the drag and drop campaign builder. When using the campaign builder, you can add a set of tasks and actions to automatically trigger based off an event or tag, and the campaigns can be very in depth, including the option to add emails, wait days, if/then statements and so much more!

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
In my opinion, Agile suffers a bit from feature bloat, which results in the software have a ton of features, but lots of quirks and bugs. It seems they spend so much time adding bells and whistles that they never improve on the core functionality of the software. At this point they've added email sending, helpdesk ticketing and other branch out parts, where they just may have been better off integrating with other systems and strengthening the core CRM.  The system frequently times out when I am using it, the search option often gets hung up, and the connections between the compartments of the software and confusing and easy to mess up- just to name a few.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
When choosing Agile CRM, I would highly recommend talking to someone at the company for a demo and starting with a free trial. There is a lot of good about Agile CRM, including a variety of API integrations as well as a lot of useful features, however the sheer amount of options and add-ons can make the software tough to use. The support for Agile can also be challanging to work with, and I've find the vast majority of times I've needed help immediately, my options were to schedule a chat for some other time or submit an email that takes up to 24 hours to receive a response.  The help videos also weren't that helpful for me, so there was a lot of trial and error. all_reviews.review_title: Amazing, we finally have a CRM that everyone loves
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
Agile is really simple to use, as with all CRMs it is basically a big address book with the ability to add notes and track deals.

It does this really well, and if nothing else the ability to keep this data well organised, tagged and updated will be enough for some users.

Where it really shines is the marketing automation features, some other reviewers have criticised these features but I feel they are being unfair.

We have contemplated other MUCH more expensive platforms and Agile won on price and features, that you can have 10 users for free and a single marketing automation or campaign allows you to test the water.

To maximise the CRM you need to:

a. Add tracking to your website
b. Add tracking to your emails
c. Add a form to your website

Once you have done this it provides great usage data on what prospect is looking at your site.

I have never found a bug, and I use it a lot for my own use and my partners business and we recommend it to all our clients.

We previously trialled One Page CRM, Pipedrive, Highrise, Insightly, Salesforce and several other packages and this one is by far the best for our needs.

The email sending features replace MailChimp and the landing pages are really handy as well. It may not be as good as Mailchimp for certain actions but being integrated has its advantages.

It works straight out the box - some minor config is required but it doesn't take long.

It has an amazing browser extension that let's you add contacts direct from the search view of LinkedIn

Finally support is awesome - a number of times I have thought their was a  bug  but  it was actually my error. The support quickly showed me screen shots on where I went wrong.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
Not too much:

1. It doesn't interface with as many other applications as I would like it to.

2. Sending emails even on the paid plan has sent by agile in the footer.

3. You can't send more then 25 emails unless you set up a campaign, this is a pain but not enough of one to devalue the tool.

4. You can't add an attachment to a campaign, only a link or a picture. Again not a total deal breaker but a tad annoying.

5. Setting up an email template and editing a campaign feels a little clunky.


Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
Don't think about it, set aside a few hours and try it out. Everyone we have recommend it to loves it!

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
Organising and managing clients, ex-clients, prospects, and all our leads.

It has allowed us to market to our existing clients and track clickthroughs from campaigns.

I would highly recommend you try it, as unlike a "leading" automation / CRM vendor who want a years fees upfront Agile is free for 10 users and a limited feature set.

We market better, we manage prospects better we have great visibility.

all_reviews.review_title: Affordable and scalable solution for small business owners
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
Agile CRM provides a robust set of features, including what you would expect from a CRM such as contact management, sales pipeline and integrations with a wide range of services.

What really stands Agile CRM out from the crowd is the marketing automation. Being able to trigger campaigns based on customer interaction with your marketing channels is an absolute winner. Once a contact is in Agile CRM I can see when they are back on my website and engage with a customer directly to help lead to a conversion.

The ability to automate the ongoing engagement with customers is priceless, and being able to provide customers with a calendar schedule to book appointments is great.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
The landing page builder / web rules (popups) builder is still a little clunky and doesn't give you the easiest interface to design landing pages or modals. The form builder is a little basic too and could do with being more thought through.

I also hate iFrames but that's the only mechanism for embedding my calendar on my website for clients to book appointments. I am hoping to see more control for the styling of the embedded calendar, either through the CRM or offering true integration rather than embedding this feature

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
This is a great low-cost product for any business owner needing to get a robust CRM without complicated setup or management. A little HTML goes a long way in designing some of the marketing elements but it's overall a winner!

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
I use Agile CRM to help manage ongoing marketing communications and to drive conversions to my sales funnel. By scoring leads and segmenting users based on behaviours I am able to create highly targeted personalised email campaigns.

all_reviews.review_title: The worst email automation tool I've used
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
The CRM part is OK if you want a very basic tool to store your leads, and do not require a lot of customization. You can easily add custom fields, but the interface is basic so I wouldn't recommend it from a visual perspective.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
For the CRM portion, the information is stored in tabs. So if you want to look at a contact record, you can tab to see their info, then tab to see their web activity, then tab to see their campaigns - it does not live on one page.

The email automation and emailing are a nightmare. You can't put an unsubscribe link in an email template - you have to add the field to each email you send, both one off and in a campaign. In text versions of the email, you can not add links. You also cannot set account wide lead scoring for things like demographic data - you have to add that to every campaign, and a demographic node counts as one, and then the score node counts as one  - campaigns are limited by the amount of nodes, so you can pretty much set up one or two emails in a single campaign before you have to transfer them to a new campaign. Also, once the campaign is running, you cannot make any changes to the email. If you have a link to a page that changes, you cannot update that link in a running campaign, and you can't see how many contacts are at varying stages of the campaign.

Agile CRM consistently lost a lot of data - campaigns would save, and I would log out, only to return an hour later and have pieces have saved. Support could only respond that I should be capturing screen recordings (which I did) and then could only say that it must be frustrating that it kept losing my work.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
I would seriously consider your business needs - the pricing for the Enterprise level of membership is highly comparable to more robust solutions like Salesforce.com without any of the limitations and bugs Agile is facing.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
Organizing business contacts and leads. I didn't realize any benefits.

all_reviews.review_title: Less than great
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
The amount of apps that connect to the cloudware seem to be great. But buggy. It looks good and gives good visual of data.
Email integration was good. Captures a lot.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
Customer support is horrible.
They sales guys are pushy and offered if I didn't like it that we could get a full refund before 30 days. NOT SO.
The cloudware is super buggy.
The apps don't always work
The dashboard is buggy. Sometimes displaying old data or not relevant.
Too easy to delete something and miss it completely.
Syncing with apps is buggy. Constantly having to delete contacts multiple times and the data is not synced correctly without a way to map the data cells being ported.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
Don't do it. Look at Zoho, ProsperWorks, Method or some other CRM that is easier to implement and that will actually work for you. Whatever you do, don't try and sync with Quickbooks.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
We are looking for a way to identify sales from multiple sources, delegate to the proper sales function or channel and convert more opportunities into sales.

I haven't realized any benefit due to the constant manipulation of the data that is poorly synced with other apps. You spend way too much time filtering and fixing than working.

all_reviews.review_title: Great Hubspot alternative for small businesses
all_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Agile CRM?
Agile CRM and ClickDesk seamlessly integrate with best of class web apps such as Shopify, Wufoo, Harvest, Quickbooks Online, Basecamp, Google Apps, and many more.

Customer support is excellent and replies rapidly.

The breadth of features and breadth of integrations AgileCRM and ClickDesk offer is unparalleled. You would have to patch together several apps to match what AgileCRM and ClickDesk do.

What do you dislike about Agile CRM?
I wish it had a more customizable interface that allowed for more of a functional workflow set-up rather than a structural database interface.

It's buggy and needs more polish.

Recommendations to others considering Agile CRM:
Try it. Agile CRM is particularly good for ecommerce and SaaS business models. Look for the new breed of full service all-in-one apps that integrate marketing automation and CRM. Another one to look at in this category is Intercom.

What problems is Agile CRM solving and how is that benefiting you?
Marketing, sales, and service.
